element_texts.text:
1863 Journal Continue
October 7th,1863. Left St. Louis late in the evening on carrs to Rolla Missouri
Oct 8th. Arrived in Rolla by day light. In the afternoon went on scout to South west and[unclear] the same evening camped at Little Piney.
Oct 9th. We camped two miles beyond Waynesville.
Oct 10th, 11th. Arrived Lebenon on the night of 11th. We stayed all night at Lebenon
Oct 12th. The evening came for us to march to Linn Creek though it was pretty late.

Journal Continue
But on the 21st of the month we had very disagreeable weather, and once had to cross the prarie 38 miles wide. So we took early start for it, but did no make it by evening, but we had to make it or freeze to death, so we went some of the boys and went on ahead of the  Unclear and command

Journal Continue
unclear eat, we left at Fort Gibson 20 men on account no horses and we left a great many at Fort Smith therefore our regiment has a great deal reduced since we left Brownsville
August? 19th. We marched 18 miles. camped on a large creek
Wednesday? it was very cold indeed. We marched about 3unclear

1868 Journal Continue
Oct. On the whole entire scout we had but one blanket to each amn, for covering of nights rest from weariness of riding. But it was very poor was of finding rest. When we did camp night.
In about the last of Oct. we moved to Camp Sigel by orders Col. William? D. Wood which was afterwards called Camp Bonneville. From there we moved to camp Livingston, in brigade with 1st Nebraska Cavalry?

1863, Journal Continue
December 10th We began to march to Batesville Arkansas. We marched 8 miles beond Laketon, and stayed.
12th, We marched 20 miles
13th, We marched 5 miles and camped near Pineary
15th, We marched 12 miles and camped near the forks of the current river. Here suther charged $8.00/1 dozen? for a bottle of Drakes plantation butters.
16th, our company (D) were ordered back in the ear of the train which we had a very large train of comissaries stakes reduced during the day but we camped at the same

186unclear Journal Continue
Dec. 16th, Continue But we were lucky to procure our tents.
17th, we stayed at the sae place all day. The road being so bad. We did not make much headway. We were then a car forwards? of the brigade, and the train also.
18th, we marched 12 mile after having no food our horses for two days
19th, we marched 15 miles and arrived at west plains and camped. Sergeant Day wet out on foraging expedition with unclear of men. Himself and 2 of the boys stopped to get something to eat and were captured.

1863 Journal Continue
Dec. 19th and there were 2 bushwakkers were shot by order of Col. Livingston acting Brigadier General
20th, We marched 20 miles and camped and unclear Arkansas line
21st, We arrived at Salem Arkansas or near Pilot the ice, and camed

1863 Journal Continue
Dec. 24th, We marcherd 9 miles it was fine sunny day
25th We marched 9 miles ad arrived at Batesville Arkansas which was the end of our destination. And fond the rebels enjoying themselves pretty well, of their Christmas sport. We marched into town without their knowing us coming, so we routed them and took possession of town.

1863 Journal Continue
Dec. 29th, Three companies of us left for Jackson Port Arkansas. We marched six miles and camped
30th, We marched through a little villiage which was called Sulpher Rock.
31st unclear Caped nine miles from Jackso Port
1864 January 1st, We stayed all the day and mustrered for pay
2nd We marched 5 miles and camped in the snow and mud.
3rd, We arrived on the unclear unclear of Jackson Port.

1864 Journal Continue
Jan 4th, Now we have arrived at the place of suffering for want of everything such as dry place to sleep. Situated on the banks of Black river we live on prok, beef and corn bread. The grain of meal were as large common size of pebbles. Flour bread not to be seen 50 miles from Jackso Port. Our horses suffering from want of something to eat as well soldiers.

1864 Journal Continue
January Third.  Cavalry Volunteers? were also in Jackson Port. Bu they were ordered away to Cirsy. And we were also received oreders to march o the same day.
11th Therefore we cross tht river on ice. our great heavy unclear waon coss the river very well without any troubles and camped on the bank. A great many negroes follow us to Batesville, as we were moving back to Batesville.
12th, We marcherd as far as Sulpher rock ad camped in the County after Forge.

1864 Journal Continue
Jan Whic was the same previous very cold indeed
13th,  We marched 10 miles and arrived to our destination. We remained only two days in camps, till we were ordered for three days scout to Smithville and in the vecinity thereof. Captured 3 rebels. Feed for our horses is indeed was very scarce. We forage from citizen every third day or scout during the whole time, therefore our horses oly starved to death.

1864 Journal Continue
February 19th. We went to forageing. There were about sixty men  in all with the train. We had 35 wagons. We wet 12 miles and camped expecting? to load up the rest of our wagons by morning, which we had some wagons loaded already.
20th Early in the morning we were attacked by squad of rebs under command of Captain Rutherford and captured our train, captured several our boys and teamsters.

1864 Journal continue
Feb, but few out of the company escaped without being injured, but I lost my horse, saddle, bridle, 2 blankets, overcoat, and Merrills Carbine. But our captain commanding stood his ground like a brave soldier till he was shot down receiving his fatal wound. We were surprised considerably for we did see them till they were in camps, yelling and shooting, so all we had to do was attempt to sace our selves if we can.

1864 Journal Continue
Feb For part our men were already in the hands of the enemy. Majority of the men were eating their breakfast some washing their faces. Some were a the house trying to procure something to eat. Therefore we were scattered all over the plantation whe the yell was made by the rebels. Our arms considerable distance from us, so it was impossible for us to come to our arms without being captured or shot down.

1864 Journal Continue
To this date I suspended? with writing. Therefore there is no particular notion is here unclear. But after the arrival of Col. W. D. Wood unclear the 11th unclear cavalry regiment, which was in spring of the year. We then evacuated the Batesville post on accont no feed no provisions for us and went Jackson Port Arkansas, which was 25 miles from the post

Journal
And ar the same time it was more convenient for boats to come up there fo the river navigable for them to run. Next day after we came to Jackson Port, there were 800 rebels attacked es but the fight did not last long, about one day, I noticed the rebels came through misunderstanding, they thought there were about 100 came down to Jackso Port on detail to unload the boats, but they find on while Brigade coming out to fight them.

Journal
So they did not make no stand at all. Afterwards we began to fought? immediately but we only remained in Jackson Port three or four weeks but while we were there we had plenty of everything. The fleet came fro us so we got aboarde of the fleet and went to Devall's Bluff, Arkansas. We stayed there

Journal Continue
about 2 months, doing Picked Guarding. Col. W. D. Wood left us at Devall's Bluff three or 4 days after we arrived there. We went on the detached service on the Rail Road, but the whole regiment were scattered by two or three Companies at each station. unclear & D comapnies were together, which D is my company.

Journal
There was one morning after we had been there about two or three weeks the rebels attacked us, under command of Col. Colemen, with 150 men and we had only 60 out of the two companies, but we stood our ground. The firing kept up for about half hour, but ther began to retreat. They had us completely surrounded, but did not hurt us for so doing

Journal Continue
Colemen reported afterwards that he had lost wounded ones, 30 men, but any of our men were touched with a fall, but they captured out Lay makers which they through frightenneww they ran down the road. The rebels being so near they took them in. But afterwards we find out we had lost good many horses, but they broke from the

Journal Continue
lines of which we were driving across the picked line. About a week afterwards we were ordered to another station but did not remain there long, and were ordered to another one which was called Stockade. The same evening we were ordered out for a scout after Rebel Shelby, we went as

far as to the place called Cercy, the whole unclear brigade, but we did not accomplish our purseants, but we lost several of our men by Bushwackers. Then we went back again to Devall's Bluff, then we remained about 2 weeks, thenpart of our en were sent to Cavalry Depot on account of them being dismounted.

Memorandum
The rest of them remained in theold camps. Soon afterwards Rebel Shelby attacked the Rail Road Stations and took in 500men of 54th Infantry, about 15 of Cavalry went out and fought them about 2 1/2 hours, and the rebels repulsed that evening nextday all the ablebodied men dah to get up.

Journal Continue
and go after Shelby, so we marched again with ten days rations, we went this timw 80 miles, we was within 9 miles from him most all the time, but still we ahd a fight with the rear guards every day until we camp. And they cross theriver and we could not go no further for our rations were giving out.

Journal Continue
so we turn back. We lost again several men by the Buswhackers and came back to our quarters once more. Then we move camps north of town, andbegan fixing up our winter quarters. We had received marching orders again, to another station, but we remained in camps

Journal Continue
for three or four days and Col. Wood had a very nice log cabin put up, but he had to move the next day, so his winter quarters did not do him no good, and we carched toBrownville station with our Brigade. We marched there in one day, the evening we arrived there

Journal Continue
it began raining very hard indeed, bt some of our boys had come there before we did on Carrs with our tents, so we found all the tents pitched. Next day we moved to another camping ground, which Brigadier General had chose for us

Journal Contiue
to camp in, and reained in camps about 4 or 5 days after had fixed unclear to winter there expecting. But we had marching orders again, but only a detail out of every regiment, therefore we set out to march forFort Smith 500 men in all.

Journal Continue
As an scout for Major General Heron, as you will find in the next forgoing pages, but we left others to build up winter quarters up, they stayed there with the intention of countering there

Journal Continue
But it is very uncertain for a soldier's abiding place. And it is also very uncertain for us now that any of us will ever get to our respective regiments anymore, for death is uncertain for we don't know how soon we may fall by the hands of the enemy on this trip.

Journal
of the trip to Fort Smith Ark. Escort for Major General Heron.

Journal Continue
Oct. 30th We set to march to Fort Smith Ark.. Arrived to Little Rock, no feed for our horses nor nothing to eat for us.
31st This morning we bought some bred and onions which made is very good breakfast. By 3 'o' clock we marched and went about 8 miles unclear camped. And The rest of the page is torn off

Journal Continue
Nov 1st Cloudy and misty day. By 12 o'clock it began raining till evening. Marched 17 miles and camped. Some of the boys went out in the country and brought in a small hog for supper. 
Nov. 2nd, Reville at 4 o'clock. We marched by daylight over rocky hills valleys and mountains, raining during the whole day. Arrived Louisburg after night after marching 28 miles. Very disagreeable time for camping.

Journal Continue
Nov. 3d. We laid? by before noon, and marched at 2 o'clock, and went only 7 miles and camped in a cane break bottom very blusty day. Left the General in town our horses well fed and had very good supper
Nov 4th, Friday. Rose very early (4 o'clock) marched very steadily till we arrived Darkenell by late evening. We cross the Arkansas river and camped in the limits of town, North west direction. I went to town and had very good supper, mostly union families living here.

Journal Continue
Nov. 5th. (Saturday) Reville sounded at 4 o'clock. Very cool this morning, turn warm by noon. Have not seen no rebels yet, but we heard some news from them, they being in the country. This morning 4 of us went to town and had a very good breakfast, but they left us behind but soon catched up. Marched 25 miles nd camped in an old field. Very oor feed for horses. I saw women ploughing this evening at this place, and on Picked? now

Journal Continue 
Nov. 6th, Sunday. Cloudy morning. Rose at 4 o'clock. Company D was in the rear guard. The advance guards run on to some Bushwhackers and killed the Capt. by name Bean. He shot 9 shots at the guards, but he received a deadly shot/ We reached within 20 miles from Fort Smith.  Camped on badger creek, no feed for our horses, plenty for men. 23 mmiles today

Continue
We captured beef cattle from those rebels about 60 heads and some sheep
Nov. 7th. We arrived to destination by 1 O'clock PM. We found the soldiers here alost in starvation and all the cavalry regiment are dismounted on account of the horses had been starved to death. No feed for horses we ae camped across

Journal Continue
We captured one Bushwhacker about 5 miles from Fort Smith. While were crossing the Arkansas river, Shortly got into quicksand, and John Adams went back to help Shortly out, and he got into it himself and he lost his saddle and eveything he had. The horses come safe but the saddle slip off.

Continue
but the other man came out safe, by the assistance of Mr. Adams, but he lost lost everything he had saving his friend's property. This the end of our Journey.

Journal Continue
Nov. 8th. We remained today grazing our horses. I have learned a great deal from home by a Cherokee Woman, learned some about my friends too.
Nov. 9th. Still at the same place, no feed for horses yet, hardly anything to eat for men. I saw one of my Aunt's negroe boys as a soldier.

Journal Continue
Nov 10th. We are still at the same camp. I took a ride around theIndian settlements, which we were camped in Cherokee Nation. There are a great many Indian Bushwhackers. We have heard they don't take no prisoners. We are layin waiting for the train to come so as todraw ration and march to Fort Scott. There were scouts sent this evening

Journal Continue
in order to meet the train it is supposed that it is captured. The citizens and soldiers here are suffering for something to eat. They are worse at Fort Gibson they only draw 4th ration for ten days. The Government supports the citizens here and at Fort Gibson too,

Journal Continute
Nov. 11th. We are still in the same camp, some o the boys went to town and got 4 bowie knives and military pocket knives and some other articles which they got on sly. There were 800 rebel soldiers give themselves up today. 75 yesterday.

Journal Continue
Nov. 12th. Still in the same camp. But we had orders to fix up to move so we had everything buckled up on our saddles, but did not move. We had our horses tied up all the day without any feed nor anything to eat for men. The Bushwhackers who we captured 5 miles from Fort Smith was hug at the guard house today, it was proved

Journal Continue
on hum as a bushwhacker and one corporal Wilson of Co. H died today, of 11th Cavalry volunteers? I went ot tonight to a neighbor and got acquainted with a nice young Cherokee Lady. Expect to leave in the morning by way of Fort Scott.

Journal Continue
13th We made a move toward Fort Gibson. Went 15 miles and camped. No feed for horses hardly anything for us, only beef and no Crackers. Very pleasant day.
Unclear 1866

Journal Continue
Nov. 25th. I dispended with writing for several days since the 13th. On the 14th, I went through to Fort Gibson with one Indian and rode 50 miles. The command arrived to Fort Gibson by 15th, bt we did not march till the 16th by 12 o'clock AM. Major General Blunt arrived then from pursuants of Price Army C.S.A

Journal Continue
We marched that evening 7 miles and camped out in the Prarie. It rained by morning. early in the morning we moved again toward Fort Scott. We marched 25 miles and camped on a little strp of timber. No feed for our horses only dry grass, of the prarie. On the 18th we marched 30 miles and campe. No provision for us.

Journal Continue
20 Sunday? We were about some about 10 miles ahead by 10 o' clock in the night we conclude we wouldlay down and sleep a little, so picked out a lowest ground we can find, and unsaddled our horses and proceed to go to bed, but we did not find much rest after all
Washington

Journal
But came very near freezing, but we stayed till morning but on the 22nd we faired well, because we came to the settlement, but I arrived to Fort Scott on the 23rd next day after the command came in.

Journal
Therefore we are camped across the creek from town but we are over there every day. We do not know when we'll leave here. We have got plenty f ration, but very little feed for horses. We have not many horses  were abandoned on the road

Journal Continue
Dec. 16th. Dismounted men left today out of our regiment going back to Fort Gibson witht the train very few of us are mounted, we have been here nearly 9? weeks, do not kow when we will leave here.

Journal Continue
Dec. 21st We left Fort Smith last Saturday moring. The same evening returned to fort Scott and stayed all night. It began raining but I started back to command and overtook them next day. It snowed last night and cleared off by morning

Journal Continue
Dec. 24th. We arrived here yesterday by 12 or 1 which the river of Nesslo? being impossible for crossing at the present time. So we we may emain here for several days. Many of the boys had gone out to hunting excursions. Peaces wrote when i trouble on the way to Fort Gibson by the author with his lover as Fort Scott.

R-Remember when in thy lonely place
O-Of thy be loved absent face
B- Be thou in good courage till we meet
E-Evermore pray that time may soon speed
R-Roving minds may in on place collect
T-Teain we'l be our sorrows never to recollect
L-Love will always with s remain
E- Each hope for a better time to fine
S-So let us for each other have faith
L-Law will soon tell our fate
I-If the Providnece guidde and guard
E-Ever always cling to each others heart

My love I can;t with you part. Love for you strong clings to my heart. I know that your sorrows are great. Must you suffer always for me.
Leave you must, but with a sad heart. You cling to my heart that can't part. With molested breast I must go. A time may come when we shall meet. Sad sorrows never more to know. Heart will ever always in Peace.

When you and I each others love shall part
Shall leave a sain on each others heart
I to some grove lonely shall go
Lye down and die as others do
All this more I have to say
Night calls e home I must obey
With good attention view these hasty lines
You will in them a question find

L-Low in spirit of state am I
U-Under any tears are my eyes
V-Voice from that beloved is lost
A-And no more of her to boast
N-Now I know ust from her part
NNothing no more conent my heart
A-Always to carry discontented mind
H-How long, will it be to meet
T-To find
I-In peace joy and glory
L-Long hope the time may
S-Soon expire
Long hope for time to tell the pleasant story. Shun the sadness, but face of love to admire. 
The first capital letters spells the lady's name

Written in an album
As over the cold september stone some name arrests the passer-by. Thus, when thou viewest this page alone
May mine attract thy pensive eye. And when by yhee that name is read perchance in some succeeding year, reflect on me as on the dead, and mark my head buried here.
January 23rd, 1865
Fare thee well and if forever still foreveer, fare thee well! Even though forgiving never gainst thee shall my heart would that breast were bared before thee.

Copies of Missionaries letters
Winneconne June 10th, 1862
Dear Robert,
As you will believe we were not a little surprised to eceive a letter from you. For we had no idea where you were. But we are glad to hear from you again, though very sorry that you are in trouble, It was not strange that they should think you dangerous, when so many creeks and Cherokees have taken arms against the government, but I hope you will soon be able to prove your innocence and find a pleasanter home, than a prisoner's home is

Copies of the missionaries's letters
It is sad to think how many have lost their homes in this war, but if they have lost nothing more than property and homes, they may be thankful for how many widows and fatherless children this wsa has made. We have now no home with them until we can find another one,but we do not know where that will be. Mr. R is teaching the school here this summer but does not know what he will do next. We would gladly go back to the Indians, but we do not yet see any opening for it.

Copies of letters from M
Mr. Robetson sends his love to yo and says he would have written but did not find time. He sent you the last Creek tract he had printed yesterday, and we will try to see that you have some more reading. I am sorry you have no Bible. What became of the one I gave you, that was so convenient for carrying about. Tell us how ou like the tract about the Sabbah. Do you have any chance of attending anything on the Sabbath? I hope so I am sure. I am glad you can write and Hope it may be a comfort and help to you.

Copies of miss. letters
We were glad you united with a church in Missori ad hope you will always seek to do that which shall be pleasing to God. And when all is done that you can do put all your trust in Jesus, the saviour of sinners. Please give our regards to Dr. Evans and tell him I am very anxious to hear from him again to know something abot our friends as we have heard nothing from them sice we left last september. We sent word about his friends

Copies of Miss.'s letters
by way of Kansas, but don't know when the ward will get through. We are sorry you have had that sad sickness but are glad you have got over it so well. We have wished somebody would go and vaccinate the Indians, fo fear the war might scatter is among them. It is said Ian Dorn has a regiment of Indians in Miss. Does Dr. Evans know whether any of our acquaintances are among

First Letter Conclude
Write again to your true friend and former teacher, Mrs AE Robertson
Remarks
This was the first letter I received from ant of my friends for 3 years. At the reception of this letter I was in Military Confinement at Alton Prison Illinois accused of being a southern sympathizer. I remained in confinement six months nd was released on Parole of honoer during the war in the limit of missouri lines. R.L

Copy of letter from the same
Winneconne July 3rd 1862
Dear Robert. We were glad to hear from you again but Mr. R writes very little now that he is teaching as his eyes are troublesome and the care of housework and my children keep me s busy that I can find almost no time for writing. I had a copy of Mathew in Creek out to send to you but Mr. R is afraid it will get lost as the tract? was withot you seeing it so I will just enclose a few English hymn, so that you may get them.

Missionary's letters
Mr. R asked Mr. Lourie to send you a Creek hymn book but I fear you have not received it. And to your questions-
Susannah and her friends were well, when we left though both her father and Grandmother had been been sick at different times. Sussana was at the mission shortly before we left and did not want us to come away.

Copy of letter from the same
Bothe your Lation classmates are dead, Washington and Charlie. Charlie begged his friends efore he died to do better than he hd done. We could not seak for some time before his death. I hope yo wll live to do good to your people but never forget that you must seek help from God. Constantly for Jesus sake, without help from him we must fall.

Missionay's letters
The ladies all reached home safely and now miss Nance is takig care of soldiers in a hospital in Washington D.C. Miss Sheperd the same in St. Losis, Miss Mills in teaching school in Michigan, and Miss A.M Turner is in the Indian orphan school in Kansas. It seems inion process are nw a Fort Gison I do hope the Indians will be glad of it, and not attack them,

Conclusion of Copy of letter
I must close my letter for I have much else to do. Can you tell me where Dr. Evans is gone? Let us know whether you hope to go back to Mission.
Affectly, AW Robertson

Missionary's letter (third letter)
Friend Robert,
We were glad to hear from you, hoping you have entirely recovered by this time. I hope you will be able to show that you never tookup arms against our government
